title: (x) ID - The International Design Magazine: text face - Coranto {Mike Y}
content:
The Last couple versions of ID have abandoned Meta, for a new -- and in my opinion -- much more appropriate serifed face. Unfortunately I dont have a scan, but would somone have the mag handy for an ID (no pun intended).   
   
Thanks.
author: Hildebrant

comments.content:
The answer is on page 19 of the Jan/Feb 2004 issue:   
"In the new design, by current art director Nico Schweizer, the workhorse typeface Scala used for body copy has been replaced by Coranto, a font created by Gerard Unger in 2000. Meta, which appeared in headlines, will be succeeded by a variety of typefaces that will change over time. We start with Gotham, designed by Tobias Frere-Jones with Jesse Ragan for the Hoefler Type Foundry."

Ahh, damn I was just saying to my partner here, that looks quite a lot like Ungers work, but couldnt place it. Thanks. I might actually read through this mag once in a while now ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20050825174519im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif). Although not being an 'industrial designer', I really find very little use for the mag, aside from something for client to flip through. On the subject of magazines, I recently picked up a subscription to STEP, which had a great layout on type in this current issue, highlighting Bilak's work and some other great articles.   
   
On a fairly different note, who designed the face for the new york times? Was that Unger? it has quite a similar 'feeling'.   
   
Cheers.   
   
Hildebrant.

Yves, I see you closed this out with 'Scala' as the answer, but it was really ['Coranto' by Gerard Unger](http://web.archive.org/web/20050825174519/http:/www.gerardunger.com/fontstore/store-coranto.html) that was the answer to the question.
